case_name: Central Inland Water Transport Corporation Limited v. Inland Steam Navigation Workers Union and State of West Bengal

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1779 and 1780 of 1973 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 1779 and 1780 of 1973. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated 14th December 1972 in Appeal No. 252 of 1971 and order dated 20th July 1973 in S.C.A. No. 262/71.

anchor.surface_text: from, the judgment and order dated the 14th December, 1972 and Order dt. 20th July, 1973 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 252 of 1971 and S.C.A. No. 262/71 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant is Central Inland Water Transport Corporation Limited.

anchor.surface_text: by the Central Wand Water Transport Corporation Limited, her-in after called the Corporation, from a judgment

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 is Inland Steam Navigation Workers Union representing workmen.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave by the Central Wand Water Transport Corporation Limited, her-in after called the Corporation, from a judgment and order of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal No. 252 of 1971 disposed of on December 14 1972. Respondent No. 1 is the Inland Steam Navigation Workers Union representing the Workmen,

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 is State of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 is the Inland Steam Navigation Workers Union representing the Workmen, and respondent No. 2 is the State of West Bengal.

facts.text: River Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. operated river service from West Bengal to Assam through former East Pakistan and employed about 8000 workmen including clerical staff.

anchor.surface_text: A few facts are necessary to be stated. There was a Limited Company known as the River Steam Navigation Co. Ltd.  hereinafter called the Company  which used to operate a river service from West Bengal to Assam through what was formerly East Pakistan. It had employed for its business about 8,000 workmen, including clerical staff.

facts.text: Due to conflict with Pakistan in 1965, the Company suspended major part of operations and undertook retrenchment due to heavy losses despite Government of India acquiring controlling interest.

anchor.surface_text: Due to companyflict with Pakistan in 1965 the Company came to grief and had to suspend a major part of its operations. Retrenchment was undertaken on a large scale because the Company had been incurring heavy losses for several years inspite of the Government of India acquiring a companytrolling interest in it to prevent its voluntary liquidation.

facts.text: Settlement arrived between Management of Company and respondent Union on August 25, 1965 valid for 5 years till end of 1969, retiring age 57 years, no retrenchment for 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of companyciliation proceedings the Management of the Company arrived at a settlement with the respondent Union on August 25, 1965 whereby it was agreed, inter alia, that the settlement was valid for 5 years till the end of 1969, that the retiring age of the workmen would be 57 years and that there would be numberretrenchment for 5 years.

facts.text: In 1966, winding up petition filed in Calcutta High Court due to indebtedness to creditors including Union of India, State Bank of India, Chartered Bank etc. several crores of rupees.

anchor.surface_text: The Companys fortunes did number improve, and, therefore, in 1966 owing to its indebtedness to various creditors, including the Union of India, the State Bank of India, the Chartered Bank etc. to the tune of several chores of rupees, a winding up petition was filed in the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Central Inland Water Transport Corporation incorporated on February 22, 1967 as wholly owned Central Government Company.

anchor.surface_text: the Company and the appellant Corporation which was incorrupt on February 22, 1967 as a wholly owned Central Government Company.

facts.text: Scheme of arrangement and compromise under Sections 391 to 394 Companies Act sanctioned by Calcutta High Court single Judge on May 3, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The Company, thereupon, made an application under Sections 391 to 394 of the Companies Act for sanctioning a scheme of arrangement and companypromise between the Company and the appellant Corporation which was incorrupt on February 22, 1967 as a wholly owned Central Government Company. The scheme was sanctioned by a learned Judge of the Calcutta High Court by his order dated May 3, 1967.

facts.text: Union appealed sanction order, Division Bench of Calcutta High Court upheld on July 14, 1967 leaving open questions on closure, settlement enforceability etc.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the order which sanctioned the scheme, the Union went in appeal before a Division Bench of the High Court. The Division Bench by its judgment and order dated July 14, 1967 upheld the order of the single Judge sanctioning the scheme. ... I am of opinion, that the questions, first, whether there is a closure of the companypany within the meaning of the Industrial Disputes Act, secondly, whether the agreement dated 25th August, 1965, is capable of enforcement,... should all be left open

facts.text: Scheme provided properties and assets of Company vest in Corporation, Corporation to take over as many staff as possible at discretion, others paid compensation by Company from GoI funds, Company closed and dissolved without winding up.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to point out that it provided, inter alia, that all the properties and assets but only some of the liabilities of the Company would vest in the appellant Corporation. It was further agreed that the Corporation would take over as many of the staff and labour of the Company as was possible under the circumstances, but as to how many would be employed by the Corporation was entirely left to the discretion of the Corporation. It was further agreed that those employees who were number taken over by the Corporation would. be paid companypensation by the Company out of funds the Government of India agreed to supply. It was further agreed that upon the approval of the scheme, the Company would be closed and on payment of all creditors it would stand dis- solved without winding up.

facts.text: Company issued notice of closure on May 3, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme, as already pointed out, was sanctioned by Order dated May 3, 1967 and, as envisaged in the scheme itself, the Company on that very day issued a numberice of closure.

facts.text: Corporation employed about 5173 out of about 8000 former employees of Company.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Corporation issued fresh letters of appointment, and out of about 8,000 former employees of the Company, the Corporation employed about 5173.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal made two orders of reference on September 12, 1968 under s.33C(2) for computation of settlement benefits and retrenchment benefits u/s 25FF.

anchor.surface_text: On September 12, 1968 the Government of West Bengal made two orders of reference purporting to be under s. 33  C   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act. By the first order of reference it asked the Labour Court to companypute the benefits companyered by the settlement dated August 25, 1965 between the Union and the Company and by the second order of reference, it asked for the companyputation of retrenchment benefits under section 25FF of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Corporation challenged 1968 references in writ petition, B.C. Mittra J set aside orders on July 15, 1969 giving liberty for fresh reference.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation challenged those orders in a Writ Petition in the Calcutta High Court... In a detailed judgment B. C. Mittra, J. held that the reference orders were misconceived and set them aside by was order dated July 15, 1969.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal made consolidated reference on October 27, 1969 to Second Labour Court under s.33C(2) with issues on transfer, binding of settlement, continuation of employment for 420 in List I, retrenchment for 92 in List II u/s25FF, closure u/s25FFF.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on October 27, 1969 the Government of West Bengal made the present companysolidated reference to the Second Labour Court in the following terms Whereas the workmen mentioned in the attached Est No. 1... List No. 1 referred to above gives the names and addresses of 420 employees. list No. 11 companytains the names of 92 employees.

facts.text: Corporation filed writ petition under Article 226 challenging 1969 reference, Ghose J struck down issue No.4 but upheld jurisdiction on issues 1,2,3.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation, thereupon, challenged this reference also by a Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution... The learned single Judge, Ghose, J struck down issue No. 4 as number entertainable by the Labour Court, but as regards the other 3 issues he was of the view that the Labour Court had jurisdiction.

facts.text: Corporation appealed Ghose J order, Calcutta High Court Division Bench dismissed appeal on December 14, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: But the Corporation went in appeal against the order of the learned Judge... The companyrt of appeal by its order dated December 14, 1972 dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave, appeal arises therefrom.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation asked for a certificate to appeal to this companyrt, but on its dismissal, this companyrt gave special leave and that is how the present appeal arises.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Labour Court has no jurisdiction under s.33C(2) to adjudicate the referred issues.

anchor.surface_text: We, are, therefore, unable to agree with the High Courts view, that the Labour Court had jurisdiction to deal with the questions referred to it u s 33 C   2 . The appeal must, therefore, be allowed.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court refused certificate under Article 133(1) on July 20, 1973 in Civil Appeal No. 1780 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1780 of 1973. Palekar, J. This appeal is from the Order of the High Court dated July 20, 1973 refusing to grant a certificate to appeal to this Court under Article 133 1  of the Constitution.
under s. 33  C   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, and the point in issue is whether that court had jurisdiction to entertain the reference.

concepts.interpretation: Proceeding for recovery of money due; Labour Court decides amount of money or computable benefit if existing right already adjudged or provided for.
concepts.unlisted_description: Jurisdiction limited to computation of existing benefits like execution proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On September 12, 1968 the Government of West Bengal made two orders of reference purporting to be under s. 33  C   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act. By the first order of reference it asked the Labour Court to compute the benefits conferred by the settlement dated August 25, 1965 between the Union and the Company and by the second order of reference, it asked for the computation of retrenchment benefits under section 25FF of the Industrial Disputes Act.

concepts.interpretation: On transfer of undertaking, workmen entitled to retrenchment compensation from transferor only, unless proviso conditions satisfied; no liability on transferee for compensation or re-employment.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation, thereupon, challenged this reference also by a Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution for setting it aside ,on the ground that the questions referred to the Labour Court did not fall within the jurisdiction of the Labour Court under section 33 C   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act.
The Corporation asked for a certificate to appeal to this court, but on its dismissal, this court gave special leave and that is how the present appeal arises.

Civil Appeal No. 1780 of 1973. Palekar, J. This appeal is from the Order of the High Court dated July 20, 1973 refusing to grant a certificate to appeal to this Court under Article 133 1  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well-settled that a proceeding under section 33 C  2  is a proceeding, generally, in the nature of an execution proceeding wherein the Labour Court calculates the amount of money due to a workman from his employer, or if the workman is entitled to any benefit which is capable of being computed in terms of money, the Labour Court proceeds to compute the benefit in terms of money.

concepts.interpretation: 33C(2) limited to computing existing rights; no adjudication of new rights or liabilities; only incidental identity inquiries.
concepts.unlisted_description: Labour Court acts as executing court for pre-existing benefits.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in a proceeding under section 3 3  C   2 , as in an execution proceeding, it may be necessary to determine the identity of the person by whom or against whom the claim is made if there is a challenge on that score. But that is merely Incidental.

concepts.interpretation: Limited to identity or minor facts necessary for computation; not principal adjudication of rights/liabilities.
concepts.unlisted_description: Permissible only for enabling computation, not deciding disputes.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ghose J struck down as not entertainable under s.33C(2); Supreme Court agrees no jurisdiction

arguments.claim: s.33C(2) proceeding is in nature of execution; only computes existing adjudicated benefits

anchor.surface_text: It is number well-settled that a proceeding under section 33 C  2  is a proceeding, generally, in the nature of an execution proceeding wherein the Labour Court calculates the amount of money due to a workman from his employer, or if the workman is entitled to any benefit which is capable of being companyputed in terms of money, the Labour Court proceeds to companypute the benefit in terms of money.

arguments.claim: Labour Court can only incidentally determine identity or minor facts for computation, not principal rights/liabilities

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in a proceeding under section 3 3  C   2 , as in an execution proceeding, it may be necessary to determine the identity of the person by whom or against whom the claim is made if there is a challenge on that score. But that is merely Incidental.

arguments.claim: Referred issues require adjudication of rights existence (like dismissal validity), not mere computation; outside s.33C(2)
No claim under s.33C(2) for matters needing s.10 reference
Under s.25FF, no liability on transferee for compensation/re-employment absent proviso

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 FF-of the Industrial Disputes Act declare what are the rights of the workmen of an undertaking which is transferred. The right is to receive-compensation as if the workmen are retrenched under section 25 F and is available only against the owners of the undertaking, that is to say, the transferor of the undertaking.

arguments.claim: 1968 reference orders misconceived due to unjustified assumptions becoming non-justiciable

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation challenged those orders in a Writ Petition in the Calcutta High Court, principally, on the ground that the references had made several unjustified assumptions, which by the nature of the frame of the references had become number-justiciable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rnor is pleased to specify the Second Labour Court companystituted by numberification No. 1727-1 B IB/3A-1/58 dated the 28th April, 1958 as the Labour

arguments.claim: Reference orders misconceived; set aside with liberty for fresh reference

anchor.surface_text: In a detailed judgment B. C. Mittra, J. held that the reference orders were misconceived and set them aside by was order dated July 15, 1969.

holdings.text: The Labour Court had no jurisdiction to deal with the questions referred to it under section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, are, therefore, unable to agree with the High Courts view, that the Labour Court had jurisdiction to deal with the questions referred to it u s 33 C   2 . The appeal must, therefore, be allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Referred issues require principal adjudication of existence of rights (transfer, binding settlement, continuation of employment, retrenchment compensation), akin to s.10 disputes, not mere computation of existing benefits under execution-like s.33C(2) jurisdiction.

holdings.text: A proceeding under section 33C(2) is generally in the nature of an execution proceeding for calculating money due or computing benefits capable of being computed in terms of money, based on an existing right previously adjudged or provided for.

anchor.surface_text: It is number well-settled that a proceeding under section 33 C  2  is a proceeding, generally, in the nature of an execution proceeding wherein the Labour Court calculates the amount of money due to a workman from his employer, or if the workman is entitled to any benefit which is capable of being computed in terms of money, the Labour Court proceeds to compute the benefit in terms of money.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows settled law from precedents like Chief Mining Engineer v. Rameshwar and State Bank of Bikaner v. Khandelwal; distinguishes suit (adjudicates rights/liability) from execution (computes extent).

holdings.text: In section 33C(2) proceedings, determination of identity of claimant or liable party is merely incidental, but principal determinations of right to relief and corresponding liability are outside scope.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in a proceeding under section 3 3  C   2 , as in an execution proceeding, it may be necessary to determine the identity of the person by whom or against whom the claim is made if there is a challenge on that score. But that is merely Incidental.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution analogy limits Labour Court to subsidiary functions post-adjudication; principal issues belong to industrial tribunal under s.10.

holdings.text: A workman cannot claim under section 33C(2) a matter not based on existing right and appropriately subject to industrial dispute reference under section 10.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly from State Bank of Bikaner precedent; ensures s.33C(2) does not usurp s.10 adjudication.

holdings.text: Under section 25FF, workmen of transferred undertaking entitled to retrenchment compensation only from transferor, not transferee, unless proviso (a),(b),(c) satisfied; no re-employment liability on transferee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 FF-of the Industrial Disputes Act declare what are the rights of the workmen of an undertaking which is transferred. The right is to receive-compensation as if the workmen are retrenched under section 25 F and is available only against the owners of the undertaking, that is to say, the transferor of the undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text; employment terminates on transfer; confirmed in South Arcot Electricity and Anakapalli precedents; no change of employers here, proviso inapplicable.

holdings.text: Even assuming Corporation successor bound by 1965 settlement under s.18(3)(c), s.25FF terminates employment; settlement term prohibiting retrenchment difficult to sustain against statutory termination.

anchor.surface_text: Where the operation of the law viz.Section 25-FF the employment of workmen stands terminated, it may be difficult to sustain it on the basis of a term in a settlement prohibiting retrenchment, though statutorily binding on the transferee as a successor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical; s.25FF prevails over settlement; arguable even vs transferor.

holdings.text: The appeal (Civil Appeal No. 1779 of 1973) is allowed, but no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must, therefore, be allowed. But there shall be numberorder as to companyts.

holdings.text: No separate orders necessary on Civil Appeal No. 1780 of 1973 as linked appeal No. 1779 succeeded.

anchor.surface_text: Since this Court had granted leave to appeal under Article 136 in special leave petition No. 2543/1973, and Civil Appeal No. 1779  NL  of 1973 resulting therefrom, has already succeeded, it is number necessary to pass any orders on this appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural disposal of certificate refusal appeal.

precedents.citation: Thief Mining Engineer, East India Coal Co. Ltd. v. Rameshwar ors. 1968 1 S.C.R. 140

anchor.surface_text: In  Thief Mining Engineer, East India Coal Co. Ltd. v. Rameshwar ors.  1  it was reiterated that proceedings under section 33 C  2  are analogous to execution proceedings and the Labour Court called upon to companypute in terms of money the benefit claimed by workmen is in such cases in the Position of an executing companyrt.

precedents.case_name: Thief Mining Engineer, East India Coal Co. Ltd. v. Rameshwar ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: proceedings under section 33C(2) are analogous to execution proceedings and the right to the benefit sought to be computed must be an existing one, already adjudicated upon or provided for
precedents.cited_holding: Labour Court called upon to compute in terms of money the benefit claimed by workmen is in the position of an executing court

precedents.citation: State Bank of Bikaner and Jaipur v. R. Khandelwal 1968 L.L.J.589

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, held in State Bank of Bikaner and Jaipur v. R. Khandelwal 1  that a workman cannot put forward a claim in an application under section 33 C  2  in respect of a matter which is number based on an existing right and which can be appropriately the subject-matter of an industrial dispute which requires a reference under section 10 of the Act.

precedents.case_name: State Bank of Bikaner and Jaipur v. R. Khandelwal
precedents.cited_proposition: a workman cannot put forward a claim under section 33C(2) in respect of a matter not based on an existing right which can be the subject-matter of an industrial dispute requiring reference under section 10

precedents.citation: The Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagapalan etc. 1964 3 S.C.R. 140

anchor.surface_text: The scope of section 33 C  2  was illustrated by this Court in The Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagapalan etc.  2 . Under the Shastri Award, Bank clerks operating the adding machine were declared to be entitled to a special allowance of Rs. 10/- per month.

precedents.case_name: The Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagapalan etc.
precedents.cited_proposition: scope of section 33C(2); incidental enquiry into identity of claimants is within jurisdiction but not determination of rights or liability
precedents.cited_holding: enquiry as to whether clerks came within the category in the award was incidental and necessary to give relief

precedents.citation: South Arcot Electricity Company v. N. K. Khan 1969 2 S.C.R. 902

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out in South Arcot Electricity Company v. N. K. Khan 1  that each one of the 3 companyditions in clauses  a ,  b  and  c  of the proviso of that section companye into play. It is pointed out in South Arcot Electricity Company v. N. K. Khan 1  that each one of the 3 companyditions in clauses  a ,  b  and  c  is to be satisfied before it can be held that the right companyferred by the principal clause does number accrue to the workmen.

precedents.case_name: South Arcot Electricity Company v. N. K. Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: each of the three conditions in clauses (a), (b) and (c) of the proviso to section 25FF must be satisfied before the right to compensation does not accrue

precedents.citation: Anakapalli Co-operative Agricultural Industrial Society Limited v. Workmen 1963 Suppl. 1 S.C.R. 730

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 25 FF. which is explained by this Court in Anakapalli Co-operative Agricultural Industrial Society Limited v. Workmen 1  is, so far as it is relevant, as follows  i  the first part of the section postulates that on a transfer of the ownership or management of an undertaking, the employment of workmen engaged by the said undertaking companyes to an end, and companypensation is made payable because of such termination  p. 745

precedents.case_name: Anakapalli Co-operative Agricultural Industrial Society Limited v. Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: effect of section 25FF on transfer of undertaking: employment terminates, compensation payable by transferor, no claim against transferee unless proviso satisfied; no right to reemployment
precedents.cited_holding: employees of transferred concern can only claim compensation against their employers (transferor); transferee not liable even as successor

anchor.surface_text: It is number well-settled that a proceeding under section 33 C  2  is a proceeding, generally, in the nature of an execution proceeding wherein the Labour Court calculates the amount of money due to a workman from his employer, or if the workman is entitled to any benefit which is capable of being computed in terms of money, the Labour Court proceeds to compute the benefit in terms of money.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 FF-of the Industrial Disputes Act declare what are the rights of the workmen of an undertaking which is transferred.
